titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vice President for Student Affairs records, 1923-[ongoing] UA.09.02.0002
titlestmt.author: Processed by: University Archives Staff; finding aid derived from MARC record using DukeMARC2EAD_ua_record_groups.xsl

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-11 18:18:52 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Vice President for Student Affairs records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Duke University. Office of Student Affairs.

did.abstract: The Vice President of Student Affairs oversees the Division of Student Affairs, involved in all aspects of student life at Duke University. William J. Griffith was Dean of Student Affairs and then Vice President of Student Affairs from 1963-1991. The Vice President for Student Affairs Records include correspondence, reports, memorandums, and other materials related to the operations of the Division of Student Affairs and cover such topics as student organizations, student housing, student government, student activities, administrative planning around student facilities and resources, and many other subjects.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection includes a wide variety of materials related to the operations of the Student Affairs office. Much of the collection is correspondence, with many reports, printed materials, and memorandums, as well as other materials.

Topics include student organizations and activities, including student government, fraternities, student living groups, interest groups, and publications; administrative activities and policies focused on student life and well-being, including student housing, student health and insurance, resources for supporting student life, and facilities for students; administrative and campus activities including arts and cultural activities such as the Duke Players, Chapel activities and services, and the Publications Board; and events of significance to the Duke community, including materials related to the Allen Building Takeover, protests and demonstrations, and many other topics.
An addition (Accession UA2018-0084) contains correpondence and subject files from Larry Moneta, VP of Student Affairs.
Some materials were removed April 2007 and now make up the Office of Student Affairs Reference Collection.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Division of Student Affairs is led by the Vice President of Student Affairs. The office is involved in all aspects of student life at Duke University, providing programs and services "that support the optimal growth of Duke students, enhance their intellectual, social, cultural and physical development, and complement Duke's academic excellence by providing opportunities for students to experience education and explore interests beyond the classroom."

The first Dean of Student Affairs was Herbert Herring, who held the position in the 1950s. William Griffith became Dean of Student Affairs in 1963, later to be called the Vice President of Student Affairs, and served for almost thirty years before retiring in 1991. Under Griffith, the office developed the Student Union and Counseling and Psychological Services, and was deeply involved in shaping the Duke Publications Board, the Duke Players, the Duke Artists Series, the Associated Students of Duke University and its successor the Duke Student Government, and many student and student-focused organizations. Griffith was Dean of Student Affairs during the Duke Vigil in 1968 and the Allen Building Takeover in 1969, involved in the administrations response and follow-up to the latter. After retiring in 1991, the William J. Griffith University Service Award was named in his honor, and the Griffith Board Room in the Bryan Center was named for William and Carol Griffith.

Maureen Cullins was the Assistant to the Vice President of Student Affairs in the late 1980s and early 1990s. She is presently (2018) the Co-Director of the Multicultural Resource Center at the Duke University School of Medicine.
Larry Moneta was the Vice President for Student Affairs from 2001 to 2019.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Records of the University's Board of Trustees which have been in existence for at least fifty years are available for scholarly research with the permission of the University Archivist. Access to records which have been in existence for less than fifty years shall be granted only by special permission, in writing, from the Board of Trustees.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records, such as search committee files or others pertaining to employment where individuals are identified, are closed for 70 years.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright for official university records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Vice President for Student Affairs records, 1923-[ongoing], Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding aid derived from MARC record, November 2014

Accessions A74-78, A80-201, A81-113, A82-113, A84-98, A80-35, A86-76, A91-69, A82-31, A93-35, A93-37, A93-41, A93-49, A95-112, and A96-25 were rehoused and processed by Tracy M. Jackson, January, March, April, June, August 2018.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Vice President for Student Affairs records were transferred between 1972 and 2018.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records including the personal information of individual donors to the University will be closed for a period of 70 years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession includes files from William Griffith's time as Vice President for Student Affairs. Alphabetized files include correspondence, reports, and other materials on the Duke Players and performance planning, the Duke University Union operations, student housing, student organizations, and other topics. Materials primarily date from the 1960s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from William Griffith's time as Vice President of Student Affairs. Included are materials related to the ten year reunion of the class of 1950, which William Griffith was involved in planning. Other personal materials were removed from this series and returned to William Griffith.

scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from William Griffith's time as Vice President for Student Affairs. Files include reports, correspdonce, and other materials related to student organizations (particularly constitutions), the Publications Board, student health insurance providers, and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from William Griffith's time as Vice President for Student Affairs. Files are partially alphabetical and include correspondence, reports, memorandums, printed materials, and other materials related to student housing, the Office of Minority Affairs, the Publications Board, the Chapel (including expansion and activities), student activities, the University Union administration and activities, materials related to racial and sex discrimination, and other topics. Included are the results of a survey administered to students on opinions about the Allen Building Takeover (called "Sit-In Study") as well as files on Title IX regulations and segregated facilities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from William Griffith's time as Vice President for Student Affairs. Files are partially alphabetical and include correspondence, reports, memorandums, printed materials, and other materials related to protests, demonstrations, and demands from African American students; the Arts and Sciences Campaign in the 1980s; the Publications Board; the Health, Physical Education, and Recreation department; several administrative search committees; proceedings of the Associated Students of Duke University (ASDU); and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists primarily of materials related to the Vigil Anniversary Reunion in 1988, with some correspondence regarding Vigils held in 1981 and narrative recounting the events of 1968 Vigil from an administrator's perspective. A copy of the Duke Chronicle from 1968 April 29 has been removed for digitization and preservation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from William Griffith's time as Vice President for Student Affairs. Files are partially alphabetical and include correspondence, reports, memorandums, printed materials, and other materials related to residential life, an AIDS task force, the development of the Mary Lou Williams Center, student insurance, a group of heads of Student Affairs at universities across the country called the Vice Presidents Group, and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from three separate accessions which arrived in the Archives at different times but which together made up a largely alphabetical run of files. The files are primarily alphabetical, with some additional files at the end of the list. Materials include correspondence, reports, memorandums, printed materials, and other material types related to policy development and decisions, fraternity activities and disciplinary actions, the President's Council on Black Affairs, Student Health programs and policies, University Union (now the Bryan Center) policies and activities, student housing, denominational chaplains, and many other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series were created or collected by Maureen Cullins, Assistant to the Vice President of Student Affairs during the early 1990s. The series includes correspondence, notes, planning documents, budgets, reports, and other materials related to the Black on White Symposium (a symposium on the experience of black students and faculty at primarily white institutions such as Duke University) and the Richard Whitted Institute (a summer program for black students in North Carolina held at Duke). Materials are arranged alphabetically, then chronologically.

Black on White: Participants' Travel and Accommodations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials on the Student Affairs Committee of the Board of Trustees, of which William Griffith was a member. Contents include minutes, agendas, correspondence, and supplementary materials given to the Committee.

Additional materials in this accession that were materials from general Board of Trustees meetings were removed and discarded; those materials duplicated materials found in the Board of Trustees Records.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records of the University's Board of Trustees which have been in existence for at least fifty years are available for scholarly research with the permission of the University Archivist. Access to records which have been in existence for less than fifty years shall be granted only by special permission, in writing, from the Board of Trustees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials primarily related to the functioning of the Student Affairs office, including staff meeting minutes, agendas, correspondence, and budget planning materials. This series includes materials from both William Griffith's and Janet Dickerson's time as Vice President for Student Affairs.
